story: The incoming storm is due to a small hole &ndash known as a coronal hole &ndash which opened on the Sun&rsquos atmosphere, unleashing a stream of solar particles into deep space. Unfortunately for Earth, we are caught in the travelling direction of the particles and it could have consequences for humanity. The solar storm could result in Southern or Northern Lights &ndash or aurora australis and aurora borealis &ndash depending on which hemisphere the solar winds hit.                Halloween 2018: Solar storms to cause &lsquoGHOSTLY-GREEN&rsquo skiesAs the magnetosphere gets bombarded by solar winds, stunning blue lights can appear over the upper reaches of the Northern hemisphere and the lower parts of the southern hemisphere.Website Space Weather said: &ldquoAs Earth exits one stream of solar wind, another stream is on the way. Estimated time of arrival: November 18.&ldquoThe gaseous material is flowing from a relatively small hole in the sun's atmosphere. Polar geomagnetic activity and Arctic auroras are possible this weekend.However, the consequences could be far more serious than the appearance of the Northern or Southern Lights.Solar Storm WARNING: Particles from the Sun to HIT Earth on November 18 (Image: )For the most part, the Earth&rsquos magnetic field protects humans from the barrage of radiation, but solar storms can affect satellite-based technology.Solar winds can heat the Earth&rsquos outer atmosphere, causing it to expand.This can affect satellites in orbit, potentially leading to a lack of GPS navigation, mobile phone signal and satellite TV such as Sky.Additionally, a surge of particles can lead to high currents in the magnetosphere, which can lead to higher than normal electricity in power lines, resulting in electrical transformers and power stations blow outs and a loss of power.A small hole &ndash known as a coronal hole &ndash opened on the Sun&rsquos atmosphere (Image: )The higher amounts of radiation also leave people vulnerable to cancer.The biggest storm known to us was the Carrington Event which occurred in September 1859.During that solar storm, the sun unleashed a series of powerful solar flares that were so powerful telegraph operators&rsquo offices experienced a surge in electricity which resulted in some buildings setting on fire.The storm was so powerful its southern auroras could be seen as far north as Queensland in Australia and northern auroras were noted as far south as Cuba.

title: Brexit deal news explained UK EU withdrawal agreement Theresa May Ireland backstop latest
story: The Prime Minister&rsquos latest proposals have already become deeply controversial with rumours of more ministerial resignations and Northern Ireland&rsquos Democratic Unionist Party ready to vote down the withdrawal agreement. But in what is considered largely as a victory by Brussels and Downing Street, Mrs May has secured a UK-wide Irish backstop, the insurance policy to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland. The mechanism became Brexit&rsquos most vexed issue because the EU&rsquos own plan was used as the building blocks for what was agreed by the Prime Minister&rsquos Europe advisor Olly Robbins and his European Commission counterparts Michel Barnier and Sabine Weyand. After proclaiming &ldquono British Prime Minister could accept the terms set out by Brussels, which would have essentially kept Northern Ireland locked in the EU&rsquos customs union and single market for goods, Mrs May has now agreed a UK-wide approach to the backstop.                Brexit news: Customs union membership is now 'basis for the future'                Brexit deal TODAY: What time will Cabinet meet TODAY?When does the Irish backstop come into force?As it stands, the mechanism will now take shape in the withdrawal agreement as a UK-wide customs union arrangement.This temporary insurance policy will come into force &ldquounless and until a permanent solution to prevent a hard Irish border is found jointly by Brussels and Westminster.Because of the toxicity in the backstop, negotiators have included a review mechanism to avoid it ever being triggered.In July 2020, officials from both sides will come together to make a decision of how to proceed using three potential options.They will either say a UK-EU free trade agreement that avoids a hard Irish border has been agreed and the backstop is no longer needed, if a solution is within reach they can extend the 21-month transition period to allow more time for talks and finally, if all else fails, the backstop will be triggered.Brexit news: Theresa May agrees deal with EU and now must convince her Cabinet (Image: )Will the UK be chained to Brussels forever?Fearful Brexiteers believe allowing a UK-wide customs backstop with no &ldquoindependent review mechanism would allow Brussels to essentially keep Britain locked in a start of constant limbo.Under the terms of the UK-wide backstop, Britain would be in a customs union with Brussels and therefore have to follow EU trade rules and be unable to sign independent trade deals in order to maintain a frictionless border.The rumoured backstop agreement can be described as a swimming pool &ndash Great Britain would be in the shallow end while Northern Ireland is in the deep.The EU has insisted the original Northern Ireland-specific backstop is buried deep within the 500-page withdrawal agreement.In theory, this means if the UK Government grows sick of following EU trade rules and customs union membership it could remove Great Britain from backstop but the ultimate fallback would come into play and Northern Ireland would remain solely in the EU&rsquos customs arrangement and single market for goods &ndash creating a border in the Irish Sea.                What is the Brexit backstop? Has Northern Ireland been split from UK?                 Brexit deal TODAY: What time will Cabinet meet TODAY?Does this mean the European Court of Justice will have influence in Britain?Ultimately, the ECJ will be the final arbiter on issues involving EU law that may arise from the Irish backstop agreement.Geoffrey Cox, the Attorney General, has discussed a &ldquojoint arbitration panel to break any future impasse during review negotiations surrounding the backstop.But EU officials believe such panels are not allowed to settle political disputes of this nature.Questions of interpreting EU law can only be settled by the ECJ, which will leave the Luxembourg-based courts with an important role to play in the UK&rsquos exit from the backstop.Could the backstop become the future trading deal?Michel Barnier&rsquos deputy Sabine Weyand told EU27 ambassadors last Friday that the UK-wide customs arrangement would become the &ldquobasis of the future relationship.She said: &ldquoWe should be in the best negotiation position for the future relationship.&ldquoThis requires the customs union as the basis of the future relationship.&ldquoThey must align their rules but the EU will retain all controls. They apply the same rules.&ldquoThe UK wants a lot more from the future relationship, so EU retains its leverage.Obviously this is still all to play for, but Brussels feels like it is in a strong negotiating position moving forward.

title: Brexit news UK EU latest deal vote European Union Theresa May customs union BBC
story: Amid fears Britain could be tied to an Irish border backstop arrangement after Brexit, the Tory MP claimed EU would not want the agreement in place because it reflects what &ldquomany EU countries want &ndash benefits of customs union membership with no freedom of movement.In a bid to get a Brexit deal agreed with the Brussels bloc and resolve the controversial Irish backstop, the Prime Minister is expected have signed up to the possibility of a permanent customs union with the EU, unless a better deal is reached within two years.The heated debate began when Mr Stewart told BBC Politics Live: &ldquoOn one hand, the Brexiteers are saying this is a surrender, a white flag, from the position of many people in Europe, this deal is far too good for Britain, which is why they are not going to want to stick with it.&ldquoFrom their point of view, this sounds like Norway with control over borders, which is what a lot of European states would want.                Brexit cost: How much has Brexit cost the UK so far? &ldquoAnd that&rsquos where they are are going to want to move us on and we have a common interest to move on.A puzzled Andrew Neil said: &ldquoWho in Europe has said it is too good for us?Mr Stewart responded: &ldquoWell,&nbspbecause they have described exactly this repeatedly over the last six months.Mr Neil said: &ldquoWho has said that?In response, the Tory MP claimed Barnier and his negotiators have &ldquodefined something very close to Mrs May&rsquos backstop proposal in which Britain remains in the customs union as being one of their red lines.The BBC host then asked if Britain will have a sovereign right to leave the backstop arrangement.The Tory MP revealed: &ldquoThe proposal, as I understand it, is there would be a Commission equally composed of British representatives, EU representatives and independent representatives that will come to the agreement on to how that was left.Brexit news: Rory Stewart claims EU view May's deal as too good for UK  (Image: BBC)&ldquoWhat will determine it, in the end, is going to be Britain&rsquos view on it. In the end, of course, in the most extreme situation, nobody will want to do that.Attempting to get clarification on the claim, Mr Neil asked: &ldquoSo, in the best circumstances it goes to some form of arbitration and therefore we do not have a sovereign right to leave the backstop.The MP said Mr Neil was &ldquoabsolutely right but Britain does not think it will end up in a backstop and &ldquoEurope doesn&rsquot want to trap us in the arrangement.Mr Neil fired back once again and said: &ldquoWhy would Europe not want to keep us into a system that would stop us from doing our own free trade deal? Why would it want that?The Tory MP replied: &ldquoBecause from their point of view, from many people in Europe, they feel this is exactly what many European states want. Which is control over immigration and unfettered access to the single market on goods.&ldquoAnd they believe that these four freedoms are inalienable and would say this is breaking the four freedoms.Mr Neil said Mr Stewart was &ldquomaking up half a dozen things in his claim, adding: &ldquoThe customs union is not related to free movement. The single market is different from the customs union. That is related to free movement.The veteran broadcaster referenced Turkey&rsquos customs union arrangement with the EU and said it does not have freedom of movement.The Tory MP said: &ldquoThe backstop arrangement proposed would be a customs arrangement going a long way beyond Turkey.&ldquoIt is not a Turkish-style arrangement. This is exactly why Europe wouldn&rsquot want this to be a permanent arrangement.Prime Minister Theresa May&rsquos draft Brexit deal, a 500-page document expected to be released on Wednesday evening, has already faced widespread criticism.Backbencher MP Daniel Kawczynski told Express: &ldquoI understand there needs to be a compromise. But I think this compromise is a step too far into the Remainer camp whereby the compromise is such that the European Union will continue to dictate the laws in this country.&ldquoThat&rsquos simply unacceptable. That is not what the British people voted for.Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson has also ridiculed the agreement and said: For the first time in a thousand years, this place, this Parliament, will not have a say over the laws that govern this country. story: Mr Macron unveiled proposals for sweeping changes to the single currency area last year, including a new budget for euro nations and the appointment of an EU finance minister to oversee it. title: brit trying to claim universal credit told he must take his first day off at his new job to go to a job hunting meeting
story: Geraint Jones, , who lives in Reading, has been trying to get help on the new benefits system after he lost his job earlier this year.He’s managed to find a new one and is due to start in a couple of weeks, but has bizarrely been told he must attend a mandatory job-hunting meeting at his local job centre anyway, or he won’t be entitled to a penny.The IT sales worker, who has also served in the RAF, told The Sun Online: “They said I still need to come in and meet a job coach.“I’m away for a few days visiting my elderly mum so they told me to take my first day off at my new job - to help me get a job!“It’s just ridiculous.”Geraint, known to pals as Taff, fears he will go into debt as a result of being unable to get help on Universal Credit during the days he’s out of work.He was trying to claim the Jobseekers’ Allowance and Housing Benefit parts of Universal Credit - just to help him for  days when he was between jobs.He waited until his final pay cheque had come through from his old job - another trap that many other claimants can fall into - to make sure his benefit wouldn’t be affected.And after spending weeks hunting, he was delighted to find a new job.But Taff’s pay will likely outweigh any benefits he could get anyway, meaning he won’t be able to get any help for the time he’s been out of work.“I’m quite worried about the next few weeks,” he said.“They say the system encourages people to work as quickly as possible but it’s in my financial interest to not start work until next month so I’ll be entitled to benefits.“It seems designed to do as much as they can not to pay out.“I’m just an ordinary people in a bit of a bad situation and just want some help to get me through.“I served in the forces, I want my little bit back that I’m entitled to.”Now Taff thinks hell not be able to claim the £ to help with his housing and bills, that Universal Credit staff thought he could be entitled to.Taffs just one of many who have had problems on the new system, which many say has pushed them into debt.But officials said it was too late now to half the whole process - even though millions of Brits have been affected by the problems.The Chancellor revealed a new funding boost which will help Brits on the new scheme, but it wont kick in for millions until at least next April.The DWP say any new claimant needs to attend a job centre interview to discuss what they need to do to find work - and whether they are entitled to cash help when they are in it.A spokesperson said: When applying for Universal Credit, people will be asked to meet with their Work Coach to agree a Claimant Commitment.If they already have a job this commitment might include ways to progress in work and increase their pay, rather than looking for work.”

title: cops are led by donkeys sun says
story: Don’t get us wrong. This country is blessed to have hard-working frontline coppers doing their best to keep us safe.One of their number — PC Keith Palmer, who died in the Westminster Attack last year — will be rightly honoured with a memorial in the Parliament he gave his le to protect.But their bosses  The Home Office  It’s hard to shake the impression our lions are led by donkeys.Perceived hate crimes are deemed more important than burglaries and low-level violence. Top cops send their rank and file off to do PR stunts for the latest virtue-signalling cause. Every day seems to bring new tales of criminals getting away scot-free.It’s no surprise we’ve lost control of our streets, not just in the capital, but across the country — where kne crime is increasing at a HIGHER rate than in London.Politicians must do more than hope to plug the dam with a bit more cash. They must rebuild a ing force.That may well involve moving mental health responsibilities to another arm of government, or slashing the bureaucracy police are stuck with.It may even be time for an independent commission to look at policing.But this sorry state of affairs shames our nation — and leaves us all vulnerable.“AT the going down of the sun, and in the morning, we will remember them...”The lines of the famous war poem have never been as true as they are this weekend,  years on from the end of an awful conflict that took millions of lives. There are some who say that a century later we should consign this conflict to history. We respectfully disagree.We must keep on teaching the war’s horrors and of the reconciliation since. From a continent that tore itself apart twice in just four decades, Europe is now bound by common and friendly ties — no matter whether a country is an EU member or not.On Sunday that will be made abundantly clear when the German president lays a wreath at the Cenotaph.It is a fitting gesture of remembrance, and of progress.JO Johnson is entitled to his view that the PM’s Brexit deal is a bit of a mess.We share many of his concerns. Mrs May has a way to go to convince us she really is bringing us true independence.But his call for a second referendum is deeply dangerous. The people have had their say.They would not take kindly to being told to change their minds by the very political elites they turned against the first time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour mp lives in social housing
story: Shadow development secretary Kate Osamor has faced intense criticism after it emerged that she promoted her son in his House of Commons job, regardless of his conviction for having £, of Class A drugs with intent to supply at Bestival in Dorset last year.Now the Sun on Sunday can reveal that Ms Osamor and her son Ishmael, , are living in social housing in Tottenham, north London - despite their earnings classing them ineligible by council guidelines.Haringey Council documents from  state that households earning in excess of £, are not eligible to apply for a social housing property.And it has been reported that , people are waiting for social housing in the borough - one of the poorest in Britain - and a further , are living in temporary accommodation due to the limited supply of properties.Ms Osamor, a close ally of Jeremy Corbyn, is paid a salary of £, plus expenses. Since being elected an MP in  she has also benefitted from £, of travel and accommodation on visits to countries including India and Nigeria.Her son Ishmael is working for her as her chief of staff and is paid up to £,. And before he resigned from Haringey council last month he was entitled to claim at least £, a year in allowances from the council.Ishmael was previously a director of two clothing companies and a second hand car sales business which was dissolved in September this year. He pleaded guilty to the drug charges on October , having brought ecstasy, cocaine, ketamine and cannabis to the music festival.Ishmael was spared prison after his barrister persuaded prosecutors he was not planning to make a profit from his £, haul of drugs.Judge Stephen Climie said the -year-old was lucky to avoid a four-year prison term and sentenced him to  hours of unpaid work instead and to pay £ prosecution costs.Osamor pleaded guilty to four drugs charges after his barrister Mohsin Zaidi struck a deal with the Crown Prosecution Service at Bournemouth Crown Court.The former Labour councillor was caught with g of ecstasy – a class A drug blamed for a string of deaths at music festivals – as well .g of cocaine, .g of ketamine and a trace of cannabis at Bestival in .Ms Osamor has denied wrongdoing in the row over her son.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: stop praying silence from charles
story: But close your eyes and imagine, for a moment, knowing from childhood exactly what job you are going to do — because you have no choice about whether or not you actually want to do it.And imagine, then, having to wait for that job to start until you are the age when most people are hanging up their work boots and starting to claim a pension.It’s impossible, right  But the Prince of Wales — the man who was born to be king — has known since the age of four that he would one day have to step into his mother’s shoes. And what a mother.They say no one is irreplaceable but I think she is — which must be such a lot of pressure for him. In short, he has spent his entire le waiting for his mum to die before he can start his dream job.And in the meantime his le, in some ways, is on hold. He was not allowed to marry the woman he loved and was instead forced into a loveless marriage.And every time he so much as expresses an opinion about anything, he is denounced as being “meddling”.So it’s no wonder that in Prince, Son And Heir, the BBC documentary this week marking his th birthday, Charles was quick to quell concerns that he would be a “meddling” or activist king, saying: “I’m not that stupid.”Declaring the role of sovereign and heir to be dferent, he said he is aware of the constraints he will encounter as king, and says his behaviour will change.I can see why he is saying that, given the amount of criticism that has come his way over the years. But when you think that he was campaigning about issues such as the environment and single-use plastic long before anyone  got on the bandwagon, it might be better to see him as a trailblazer than a meddler.I admire that he has a voice.And when he is king I think he should use it — not be silenced by the pressure of the role.He has a very broad range of knowledge and he is absolutely passionate. We live in a society where everyone has their say — so why shouldn’t he In fact, I thinkhe visited Europe he might help with Brexit.There is no doubt the Queen is a hard act to follow — when the time comes, that is. Now Charles is  he is the longest serving heir to the throne in history. And he may have years to go, as the Queen looks and sounds fantastic .But we should stop maligning Charles and start supporting him.He is a good man and there is no doubt he is dedicated to the job. He is mature enough to know how to do the job well and he certainly knows what is expected of him.He has brought up two fantastic sons that any parent would be proud of.And he really is passionate about changing the world for the better.It has been more than  years since he set up his Prince’s Trust charity.Last year alone it helped nearly , young people get into education, training and jobs. It is simply fantastic.He is deeply committed to his fantastic we, who is very down-to-earth and great fun .He is also passionate about promoting women’s issues, so whatever you think of him you must give him credit for that.I believe very strongly in the monarchy. I would do anything the Queen asked me to do.The Royal Family are a great thing for our country and something to be very proud of.In a world of increasing uncertainty, they are this country’s rock and foundation. We should all get behind Charles and celebrate him as our future king.Apart from anything , we need all the stability we can get. ANYONE living in London will be unsurprised to hear that there are now a record number of people sleeping rough there.Figures show there were , rough sleepers in the capital between July and September – the first time the total has exceeded , in a three-month period.It’s awful and it’s shocking to see people sitting in the cold begging for money.And it’s hard to know how to help. Of course, the temptation is to give money but obviously that’s just a short-term fix.Night shelters are a good short-term solution. Buthomeless people don’t get involved with a network that can really help them, it’s unlikely their circumstances will ever change.My husband Paul volunteers with the fantastic charity West London Mission . It offers homeless people a hot shower, new clothes, a meal and a decent night’s sleep.But it also offers access to project workers who will help people change their circumstances.Its aim is to empower and help homeless people become part of a community, because that’s the start of them getting off the streets, into accommodation, then into work.There are so many reasons that people become homeless. Some have lost their job and can’t afford rent, or they’ve fallen out with family and turn to drink and drugs.They might have mental or physical health problems, a history of abuse or a dficult childhood moving between foster homes.But where there is le, there is hope. Paul has been working with one guy who was homeless and hopelessly addicted to drugs.But, over time, he has got clean, found a place to live and, last week, got a job at a restaurant, which is what he was doing before he got involved in drugs.He’s got his le back, basically. It does happen.Soyou are worried about homelessness, think about donating to an organisation such as WLM. Better yet, volunteer your time and skills.Even just helping someone to fill out a form, which can be incredibly dficult for some people, can make a huge dference and is so rewarding.TODAY is Remembrance Day and I wear my poppy with pride. This year I will particularly recognise all the true heroes from World War One. I thank them for their service, and remember we are always in their debt.It is so important we never forget the sacrice they made and the bravery they showed.I doubt there will ever be another generation like them. AS a rule, I like to live and let live. But I really had to roll my eyes at the story of -year-old Dutch pensioner Emile Ratelband, “who identies as a -year-old” and is fighting to legally change his age by  years so he can get more work and attract more women on Tinder.Emile, above, was born on March , , but says he feels at least  years younger and wants to change his birth date to March , .His argument is thattransgender people are allowed to change sex, he should be allowed to change his date of birth because doctors said he has the body of a -year-old.So does that meanI feel like a supermodel inside, I can I get my job title legally amended Or maybe at  I could identy as  so I can have access to my pension SO the six men arrested for burning an effigy of Grenfell Tower are in hiding and relying on friends and relatives to bring in food and drink. Still, they are yet to speak out – or apologise.What beggars belief is not just that these sick men thought that no one would notice nor care when this footage emerged on social media – but really that they are unhinged enough to do it in the first place.I’m pretty sure about one thing, though. No matter what consequences they will face for their actions from the law, they will never, ever live this down in the eyes of the world – and nor should they.I’m talking about Michael Douglas, . When he was awarded with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame for more than  years in the entertainment industry, he gave his father, Kirk, a kiss on the lips to celebrate.In my experience there comes an age when your kids don’t want to kiss you – particularly on the lips and particularly your dad.It’s part and parcel of growing up that your kids don’t even want you to breathe, let alone kiss them.In fact, everything you do embarrasses them. But, given that Kirk Douglas is , maybe it’s just a reminder that things come full circle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in his le where he’s not just  per cent wrong, he’s  per cent right as well.Glorious television.Dianne: “Stephen Fry.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Sesame Street’s Big Bird lives in what street ”Oliver: “I don’t know.”Joe Lycett: “A bird in the hand is worth two in the what ”Jon: “Foot.”And Bradley Walsh: “Which former EastEnders star presents the Sky One series Extreme World ”Zoe: “Barbara Windsor.”CELEBRITY Hunted contestant and former Commando Johnny Mercer MP has faced a stark choice this past month.The eternal humiliation of being beaten by Chris and Kem, off Love Island, on the Channel  hide ’n’ seek game.Or two weeks in a confined space with a clearly smitten Kay Burley.Heroically, he chose the latter, enduring her attention and pet namewith the same sort of grit that probably saw him through three tours of Afghanistan.Then, last week, he sneaked off for an unscheduled visit to his we, Felicity, and Burley completely lost her s***.Lost it so badly, in fact, that she threw herself at the mercy of a passing bread truck driver, which led to the best update of the series: “Kay Burley is currently in a -ton lorry, on the M, between junction  and .”She was quickly grassed up, of course, then apprehended at the Warburton’s depot, without the need for a vet or a tranquilliser dart.But while it’s a poorer show without the old mad-whack, there’s still plenty of mileage left in this gripping series.AJ Pritchard is cornered in Shropshire, Olympic silver medallist Louis Smith has just been found hiding in his mate’s Jacuzzi showroomand Baldrick-brained duo Chris  Kemhave somehow given everyone the slip.But as for Johnny Mercer  He’s probably smuggling himself back to the Mouth of Hell fort, in southern Helmand, just for the relative peace and quiet. Paul Merson: “For me it’s six and a half of one and a dozen of the other.”Graeme Souness: “The only one with potential is Martial and Pogba.”Dion Dublin: “Liverpool are in second and a half gear.”And Charlie Nicholas: “Pogba’s either brilliant or a showpony. He played OK last week.”THIS week’s Doctor Who episode introduced us to the Demons Of The Punjab, who turned out to be nothing of the sort.They were just morbid sods who mope around the universe “honouring those who die alone”, like soldiers, holy men and Brendan O’Carroll on For Facts Sakes.No actual science-fiction storyline to speak of then.But that’s not really the point of this viewer-shedding series, which has already got on its high horse about sexism, Donald Trump, American segregationist racism, men giving birth and gun control.Kind of inevitable, then, that the BBC would eventually pour a bucket of its self-loathing sick all over the British Empire, via the partition of India in , with an episode that was every bit as historically powerful as Carry On Up The Khyber.The key dference, of course, was that Bungdit Din and his Burpers weren’t actually being used as a means of brainwashing children.Because If you were expecting Doctor Who to present the flip side of Britain’s relatively benign rule in India , then you’ll also be waiting for the episode where Jodie Whittaker lands in a Soviet gulag and starts teaching children about the brutal idiocy of Marxism.The BBC just doesn’t do anything other than its own left-of-centre view, these days – or irony by the sounds of things.As it’s just been revealed there’ll be no festive episode of Doctor Whobecause it’s “run out” of storylines.Run out  RUN OUT How the hell can a series run out of ideas when it hasn’t had any yet This Morning, Thursday: “Coming up, at quarter to , the rise of the penis filler, Doctor Ranj is here to answer your questions.”The show’s other penis filler, Martin Lewis, will answer them on Monday.IT seems almost wrong to single out just one programme from Sunday’s beautul Armistice Day coverage, but the year’s most meaningful TV awards should probably all go to BBC’s They Shall Not Grow Old, made by Peter Jackson, whose astonishing film gave a voice, laughter, tears and colour to some of the extraordinary men who survived the - trenches.Those of us who watched it, on Sunday, are unlikely ever to forget the experience. Those of you who didn’t, must catch up with it on the BBC iPlayer.Be sure, though, to watch it right through to the credits’ last chorus of Mademoiselle From Armentières, where it names the veterans who have all long since passed but whose memories and souls have never seemed more alive and unforgettable.“It’s quite hard to put your finger on it.”I’ll bet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: martin lewis free financial education textbook
story: Well, no, actually. It’s far more important than that. Money is an issue of wellbeing.Financial problems are one of the biggest contributors to orce, mental health issues, losing the roof over your head, custody of children and even suicide. And our nation has a real problem with financial capability.That’s why I passionately believe all our children should have financial education at school. While some may say it’s the parents’ responsibility, that doesn’t work when so many parents are struggling to understand financial issues themselves.In , I was involved in leading the successful campaign to get financial education on the English national curriculum, split across Maths and Personal, Social, Health and Economic education .It hasn’t made much dference. The Government put no resources into it.So we kept campaigning. Last year the Government said it would love to see a textbook, but couldn’t or wouldn’t fund it.So I made a donation to cover all costs to the Young Money charity. And last week, , free copies of the first curriculum-mapped financial education textbook Your Money Matters was sent to every English state school .It covers saving, budgeting, borrowing, working, tax, student finance, risk and reward, security and fraud and a lot more. It’s also available as a free PDF.I’ve been surprised at how many grown-ups have downloaded it to go through it with their kids, but ended up telling me they’ve learned something too.Companies spend billions advertising, marketing and teaching their staff to sell, yet we don’t get ANY buyers’ training. That needs to change. Yet the textbook by itself won’t do that.Soyou’re a parent, politely ask a teacher or headteacherthey got the textbook . . .  and plan to use it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu army emmanuel macron angela merkel latest
story: Merkel declared there should be an integrated European Union military, recalling the lessons of the First World War and the isions that led to the conflict.Speaking to MEPs today about the future of Europe, Merkel said the continent should take its fate fully into its own hands.Echoing comments made by French leader Emmanuel Macron last week, she said: We should work on a vision of one day establishing a real, true European army.Merkel added that such an army would not undermine the US-led military alliance NATO but could be complementary to it. It should include common development of arms industry, she said as well as an EU-wide arms export policy and crucially a European intervention force.It came a day after a senior minister from the French Government called for the EU to become a powerful new “empire” to rival the US and China in an interview which will infuriate Donald Trump.Merkels remarks today in the EU parliament drew loud applause in the legislature but also boos from euro-sceptic members.One of them was chief Brexiteer Nigel Farage, who said: Its a European Union that we are told is now to become an empire - a militarised European Union.A European Union that has launched a new Cold against the United States of America.One hundreds years on from the Armistice we should genuinely be worried.The idea that this new militarised union is somehow a recipe for peace I suggest you sit back and think a little bit more carefully.Maybe you should all re-read history because the European project was set up to stop German domination and what you have seen today is a naked take-over bid.Yesterday French finance minister Bruno Le Maire said Europe must be strong enough to defend itself in the future - words the US president called insulting.Le Maire controversial calls for a new superstate came as he backed Macron’s and Merkels plan for a “real European army”.Le Maire suggested Brussels should go one even further and establish itself as an “empire”.Its about Europe having to become a kind of Empire, as China is. And how the US is, the French finance minister told the German newspaper Handelsblatt.After being quizzed by the newspaper on his comments, he added: “Do not get me wrong, Im talking about a peaceful empire thats a constitutional state.I use the term to raise awareness that the world of tomorrow will be about power.Power will make a dference: technological power, economic, financial, monetary, cultural power will be crucial.Trump has blasted Macrons idea for the European Union to build an army to protect itself from the US as insulting.The US President tweeted: President Macron of France has just suggested that Europe build its own military in order to protect itself from the US, China and Russia.Very insulting, but perhaps Europe should first pay its fair share of NATO, which the US subsidises greatly!It comes three days after the French President said the US is as big a threat to the EU as Russia and China and called for a “true European army” to defend the bloc.In an extraordinary attack on the US president, Macron lumped Washington together with Moscow and Beijing as Europe’s biggest foes.The arch euro federalist insisted only a fully fledged EU defence force can protect the continent against the trio’s aggression.He said: “We have to protect ourselves with respect to China, Russia and even the United States of America.“We will not protect the Europeans unless we decide to have a true European army.”The French president lashed Mr Trump for deciding to pull the US out of a nuclear treaty with Russia that was signed during the Cold War.He raged: “When I see President Trump announcing that he’s quitting a major disarmament treaty which was formed after the s euro-missile crisis that hit Europe, who is the main victim  Europe and its security.”Mr Macron made the comments in a radio interview from the town of Verdun - the site of a major WW battle - as he tours the Western Front ahead of Remembrance Day.They were welcomed by the EU Commission, which said it has already put the wheels in motion for the eventual creation of a euro army.A spokesman beamed: “If there is a Commission that has put forward the need for a meaningful defence identity for the EU, it’s this Commission.“President Macron has been consistently putting forward this narrative for a stronger Europe that empowers and protects.“This is totally totally compatible with our work and all contributions from our EU leaders, and especially from President Macron, are very much welcome.”But the remarks were savaged by former British Army commanders, who said the revelations showed why the UK must pull out of the EU’s defence plans.Major General Julian Thompson, who led British forces in the Falklands, told The Sun: “The EU Commission now openly admits it has created the preamble to an EU army.The UK is in that preamble and risks being kept in it.“Ministers must withdraw or risk losing forever whole chunks of the UK’s democratic control over defence.”Colonel Richard Kemp, a commander of UK troops in Afghanistan, added: “This is precisely what eurosceptics have been warning about.“It is time for ministers now to take notice and rein in what they have agreed since the referendum.They have been led astray in the most crucial area of sovereignty.”And Tory MEP Geoffrey Van Orden, a former British Army Brigadier, raged: “Instead of th century dreams of French-led European grandeur, President Macron should be helping build Western solidarity.“That means helping and not obstructing a strong partnership with Britain and strengthening the NATO alliance.”

title: brits wont need a visa to travel to europe even if we get a no deal brexit eu confirms
story: UK citizens will be able to visit the EU for up to three months at a time without having to get new documents - eventhere is a No Deal Brexit.The European Commission today unveiled plans for a new visa regime after Britain leaves the EU in March next year.Eurocrats said: The European Commission has today proposed to grant UK citizens visa-free travel to the EU after the United Kingdoms withdrawal from the European Union.It would mean that UK citizens would not need a visa when travelling to the Schengen area for short stays of up to  days in any -day period.Brits who want to work in Europe, or visit for more than three months, may still need to get a visa.And holidaymakers wont be able to use the fast lane at passport control - meaning there could be much longer queues for British people at European airports.The commission also warned that under a No Deal scenario, British driving licences and pet passports could be useless on the continent.The new regime will come into force in four monthsBritain ends up crashing out of the EU without a withdrawal deal.Butwe do get a deal, it will only apply after the end of the transition period which will conclude in December .The EU said that the offer of visa-free travel will be withdrawnthe UK refuses to let Europeans come in without a visa.Theresa May has already promised not to impose visas on holidaymakers from Europe.But it was previously feared the EU would charge Brits £ or more for a permit to enter after Brexit.Todays announcement applies to all the countries of the EU except Ireland, plus Norway, Switzerland, Iceland and Liechtenstein.Freedom of movement between the UK and Ireland is already guaranteed under a separate treaty dating back to .A Government spokesman said: A UK government spokesperson said: We welcome the proposal by the European Commission which reflects the future relationship that the UK wants with the rest of the EU.We have been clear in our proposals that we want to ensure reciprocal measures on visa-free travel for tourists and short term business visitors with the EU.”Anti-Brexit campaigners claimed the new rules will hurt British citizens who spent large parts of the year abroad.Lib Dem MP Tom Brake said: This will come as a real shock to those who spend their winter months in Spain or Portugal and will now see additional costs and potential queues providing extra baggage.

title: ed bowen nicola boraston loses leg saving girlfriend
story: Ed Bowen, who medically died in the incident and had to be resuscitated in an ambulance, sacriced himself to save partner Nicola Boraston as they walked home at .am in the morning.The incident unfolded in the Stokes Croft area of Bristol when the pair were passed by a car being driven up the hill ahead of them.The out-of-control vehicle then began to reverse at speed towards them and swerved off the road.Ed, , leapt into the path of the car to push Nicola out of the way and she was left with only minor injuries.However the back of the car pinned Ed to a retaining wall of a garden, crushing his left leg and pelvis, before moving forward and allowing the wall to collapse on top of him.He underwent  hours of surgery, and spent two weeks in intensive care at Southmead Hospital following the incident on October .Surgeons were unable to save his left leg and had to amputate it just below the hip.He now faces months of recovery in hospital from his shattered pelvis and years of rehabilitation.I remember the car hitting me, but I dont really remember anything too much after that, he said.I have spent most of my working le in care work so it feels weird and a challenge to switch to being cared for now.Police arrested the driver, a man aged  who has not been named, at the scene and later released him on bail.Friends of Ed, who is well known in the Stokes Croft area of Bristol as a skateboarder and tattoo artist, have set up a GoFundMe page.Now, three weeks after the le-changing crash the couple have been overwhelmed by an outpouring of support.The GoFundMe page set up to help Ed and his family when he is eventually discharged from hospital has already smashed its initial target three times over.One of the organisers said: Ed and Nic have honestly been the bravest most inspirational team during this whole time.I cant explain in words how amazing these two are, and as you can imagine, everyone in Southmead Hospital now loves Ed for his relentlessly positive outlook throughout.Unfortunately, it is going to be a long journey for rehabilitation and as you can imagine there will be a lot of pressure for Ed when he comes out of hospital.Due to the accident Nic and Ed wont be able to work, so with your help, we would like to relieve any financial strains that they will have to meet.It will make a world of dference by taking away any added stresses when they leave the hospital. At this point Im sure you can agree this dream team dont need to go through anymore than they already have, they added.The response has been amazing, said Ed.I have had so many messages from people which have really touched me. title: thomas cook flight birmingham airport near miss object
story: The Airbus A was at a height of ft when it narrowly avoided a potentially catastrophic collision before touching down at Birmingham airport.A report by the UK Airprox Board which investigates near misses said the pilot believed the object was “some sort of balloon or drone”.It passed “directly beneath” the jet which had flown from Palma in Mallorca. The pilot estimated it was just ft away.The aircraft, flying at more than mph, was around three miles north west of the airport when the incident happened just after  am on July  this year.The report rated it as a Category A incident, meaning there was a serious risk of collision which had only been avoided by “providence”.If the object was a drone, it was being flown at more than double the legal maximum height of ft for the gadgets.Drone operators are also expected to say well clear of flightpaths approaching airports.Anyone convicted of endangering an aircraft with a drone can be jailed for up to five years.A Thomas Cook Airlines spokesperson said: “We can confirm that on approach to Birmingham, pilots operating MT on  July  reported seeing a drone or balloon.“Safety is always our first priority and while these sightings are rare, we encourage all of our pilots to report anything of this nature.”The incident is the latest in a series of near misses involving drones and airliners in UK air space.Earlier this month it was revealed that a Swiss International Air Lines flight from Zurich approaching Heathrow came within ft of hitting a drone at ,ft over the Richmond area in South West London.It was disclosed last month that a Virgin Atlantic jet on the same flightpath to Heathrow came within ft of hitting a drone near Clapham Common after a flight from Delhi.It was reported in March that near misses involving drones had tripled over the last two years with  reported last year after just  in .A recent study, part-funded by the Department for Transport, found that a mid-air collision between a lb drone could critically damage a plane windscreen.

title: brett corbett cerebral palsy human bridge glace bay
story: Brett Corbett, , of Nova Scotia in Canada, was shown in a sickening video – that has gone viral – being taunted into lying face-down in the water while pupils walked onto his back.In the distressing clip, a group of about  kids from Glace Bay High School, hurling profanities at the teen, can be seen standing on a bank, while Brett, in dark clothes, is ankle-deep in the stream.Holding his arms forward to steady himself, he carefully lowers his body into the water, as a girl in knee-high boots can be seen standing nearby.Once he is lying face-down in the stream, she steps forward, standing right on his back and uses his body as a launching pad to spring across to the bank on the other side of the water.The distressing clip has sparked outrage in the community, and prompted a -strong rally to be held outside the school yesterday in support of the bullied boy.Brett told Global News: “I was freezing. No one tried to help me.”In an interview with CBC, he explained: “At first it started as a dare. But then someone threatened to push me in the Burr-Bank [stream’s name] and said ’Get on your gut’, and a girl walked on my back.”Unsurprisingly, the teen said the bullying made him feel “sad and upset”.CBC said the dad of one of the students involved in the incident formally apologised over the weekend, and said his son took responsibility for what he did.He told the network: “This was an awful, awful situation that nobody should have to endure.”According to Fox News, Brett has accepted his classmates’ apologies but has urged pupils to stop any further bullying.His mum, Terri McEachern, said she was amazed that her son had forgiven those who abused him.She told the Washington Post: “It’s just heart-breaking. This is his mind-set.Children with disabilities have the most amazing gts in the world, they don’t see bad in anyone. They see so much good in everybody.”His mum intends lodging a formal complaint with the high school.Cape Breton-Victoria Regional Education Centre said school staff are “leading a restorative practice process” with the school community, including parents.Yesterday, a group rally was held outside Glace Bay to send a message of support to the bullied teen, and show he is not alone.Organiser Dionne Dermody told CBC that the boy’s story had upset her, as she has experience of working with people with cerebral palsy and “to see Brett hurt like that really pulled at my heart.”

title: dog drinks owners pint belfast pub

title: mystery of ancient computer found among the remains of 2200 year old shipwreck
story: The freakishly complex Antikythera Mechanism is believed to have used bronze cogs and levers to predict the phases of the sun and moon.It may even have been capable of calculating the course of planets and stars through the night sky.Many have attempted to reconstruct the assembly of cogs, wheels and levers.But engineers and mathematicians alike have been struggling to understand the complexity of the Antikythera Mechanism since it was discovered in the s.The device was found just off the small island of Antikythera between Greece and Crete, and an expedition has been funded to recover more artefacts from the device.The machines precise uses and capabilities remain a mystery.But it was operated by hand, and was probably cranked by priests to awe audiences with predictions of impending eclipses and other celestial alignments.It fell to the seabed after the ship carrying it was wrecked upon rocks some , years ago.What is known is it was built by the Greeks and used Babylonian calendar and star observations to calculate the movements of the sun and moon to predict eclipses and equinoxes.How many cogs made up the original device is unknown, but the number is believed to be between  and .Others argue there may have actually been two dferent devices carried on the ship, with their components having become mixed up.But the complexity of a device so old as left experts surprised and impressed.The device predates Nicolaus Copernicus’ heliocentric planetary system by some , years.If archaeologists are right, that advanced level of astronomical study, maths and mechanics were not achieved again by mankind for another  years.A recent find from the expedition found a heavily encrusted bronze disc, about cm wide.An article in the Israeli publication Haaretz declared it to be a lost cog from the Anikythera mechanism itself.It carried the sign of a bull — Taurus — and seemed to prove the machine was more complex than many dared dream.The bronze disc had four protrusions, large cog-like teeth.It’s since been X-rayed and scanned.But other archaeologists have been quick to point out the new report overemphasises the importance of the bronze disc.The four protrusions were cogs, they’re unusually crude for such an intricate device.At best, the bull-disc could have been an ornamental piece attached to the Antikythera Mechanism’s case.

title: the watcher new jersey stalker letters children
story: During three haunting years, the obsessed oddball sent a series of bizarre handwritten notes to the Broaddus family at their six-bedroom New Jersey home.Maria Broaddus revealed the spooky ordeal gave her nightmares including one which involved a man “carrying a pitchfork and calling to the kids.”The first letter arrived just three days after the family moved into the £, large detached home in the district of Westfield in June .“Dearest new neighbour....allow me to welcome you to the neighbourhood,” the letter began before revealing his family have been stalking the Dutch colonial-style home for DECADES.“ Bouled has been the subject of my family for decades now and as it approaches its th birthday, I have been put in charge of watching and waiting for its second coming.“My grandfather watched the house in the s and my father watched in the s. If you were upstairs you would never hear them scream,” he wrote.The stalker also wrote: “I see already that you have flooded  Bouled with contractors so that you can destroy the house as it was supposed to be“Tsk, tsk, tsk… bad move. Maybe I am one.The couple still has no idea who was behind the letters, but cops have suspected it was someone within a -yard range of the house.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl epic tantrum school nativity play spider man

title: pm in denial as she tries to win round mps to her brexit deal in the commons
story: Every week Theresa May opens with the same stock answer - this week, it was a glorious understatement.“Mr Speaker, this morning I had meetings with ministerial colleagues and others, and, in addition to my duties in the House, I shall have further such meetings later today.”At a moment of peak danger in her premiership, this inevitably had them rolling in the aisles.Seeing troublesome ministers one by one in a desperate plea for them not to resign over her Brexit deal is hardly the usual “meetings with ministerial colleagues.”And for once the Leader of the Opposition could smell blood and began by asking the correct questions.Tory MPs sat on their hands looking like they might cry as Jeremy Corbyn began to gently fillet her looming Brussels orce deal.Asked directlyBritain could leave the so-called Irish backstop off our own bat, when we choose, without the EU stopping us, Mrs May turned to waffle.I am aware of the concerns that there are, that we dont want to be in a position where the European Union would find it comfortable to keep the UK in the backstop permanently. Thats why any backstop has to be temporary.Which is what you might call a total non-answer - and another glorious understatement.The fact she dodged it did not go unnoticed on the green benches behind her.And the PM could have been in real trouble had Mr Corbyn hammered the point again and again.He might even have been cheered on by Tories desperate to know the extent to which their own boss has climbed down to the might of Brussels.But as ever he was off on a tangent, frittering away an easy win.SCORE: May , Corbyn

title: passenger cathay pacific nut allergy peanuts onboard
story: Sophie Marriott, , said she was now terried about tomorrow’s Cathay Pacic flight to Sydney, with no guarantee she would not be surrounded by other passengers eating the nuts.Speaking to the Sun Online, Sophie broke down as she said: “I’m terried.“I can’t explain how scary it is to go through anaphylactic shock.“The thought of being in the air, in a confined space – it’s terrying.”Sophie said she had initially booked the flights - costing £,with her partner months ago - flagging her nut allergy immediately.The young woman, of Saint Albans, Herts, said she was then given a form for her doctor to sign that would guarantee crew would not serve peanuts to the passengers in her cabin.But she said her doctor took issue with one of the paragraphs in the statement, which reads: “The passenger’s peanut and or other nut allergy condition do not pose any serious risks to his her health given the conditions inflight as stated in attached.”She explained: “It says that there would be no risk of me having an allergic reaction.“But I’m still at risk, there’s always a risk.”The young woman said she had even started wheezing while on a train and sitting next to someone eating peanuts - showing just how deadly the food could be for her.Sophie then provided a statement from her doctor confirming her peanut and nut allergy – but was told last week by the airline it wasn’t enough.The marketing worker said: “I provided this for proof – why they need proof I just don’t know.“Even though they know I have a peanut allergy, they are still going to serve peanuts as a cocktail snack.“I don’t know what  I can do.”Anaphylactic shock is a severe and potentially fatal reaction to a trigger such as an allergy.It normally comes on suddenly, and gets worse very quickly.Symptoms include:A sufferer may also display symptoms of allergies, such as an itchy raised rash , feeling or being sick, swelling or stomach pain.Cases of anaphylaxis can be fatal - like in the case of Megan Lee, who an inquest heard likely died of an anaphylactic shock after eating a meal from the mice-infected Royal Spice takeaway in Oswaldtwistle, Lancashire.It comes after -year-old Natasha Ednan-Laperouse died from an allergic reaction while flying with British Airways.The young woman had eaten a baguette from Pret A Manger that had not sufficiently labelled there were sesame seeds inside the sandwich.Sophie said Cathay Pacic yesterday gave her a second medical clearance form about .pm – and told her they needed it ed by the end of the day.Sophie then tried to get a doctor to look over the form but was told the timeline would be impossible.The young woman said she was now desperately trying to get the form signed today – and still didn’t knowshe would fly tomorrow.She said: “The anxiety it is causing – I just don’t know.“I was in tears all day yesterday, I’ve never been put in this position before.“It’s just terrying for me to be sat with everyone eating peanuts.”Cathay Pacic told her to delay her flight, but she said the trip was for a family wedding.She said: “I know it sounds silly – I paid a huge amount of money for this flight and the holiday.“It’s a hell of a lot to throw away because they won’t do this small thing.“At the moment, I literally don’t know what to think.”Cathay Pacic said: “Our team has been trying our best to assist her.”The Sun Online has contacted them for further comment.

title: abu bakr al baghdadi search syria hajin
story: The Sun Online was alongside the battle-hardened warriors as they targeted the warlords henchmen and family in their stronghold of Hajin, east Syria - near where al-Baghdadi is thought to be hiding out.The operation comes just weeks after the so-called Invisible Sheikh ordered the execution of  of his followers for disloyalty from his secret bolthole, which is said to be close to the Iraqi border.“In other battles, the jihadists had other places to run to, but in Hajin they have nowhere to go,” said Commander Havel Ronnie Walat of the Syrian Democratic Forces, which has been fighting ISIS since .“ here it is only the true believers left and they will fight to the death,” he chillingly added.The father of two - who has fought ISIS in Raqqa and Manbij - believes that those Islamic extremists currently left in Hajin includes, mostnot all of ISIS top leadership.In addition to al-Baghdadis relatives many of those still in the area are thought to be the most dedicated of the foreign fighters.“About two months ago we captured this British doctor. He was trying to get to escape to Turkey,” recalls Havel Ronnie.But here is signicant numbers of other foreigners here too - not just British – but many of the top leadership, who are Saudi, Chechen or Iraqi.”ISISs so-called caliphate has been left virtually decimated since they lost their de-facto capital, Raqqa, in Syria last year.However, according to the Havel Ronnie in and around Hajin the bloodthirsty group still control around  square kilometers of villages spotted along the Euphrates river and dislodging them will be extremely dficult.“ISIS have had over five years to prepare, and they have built tunnels and placed IED everywhere… they also know the terrain very well,” he states.“It is very slow work [and] we are having to take it, house by house, metre by metre.”The American-backed coalition recently suffered a major setback last month after the extremists launched a series of counter attacks using the cover of sandstorms.“The sandstorm lasted for almost three days and we could only see meters in front of us,” a female commander explains of that attack.Luckily they suffered no losses at that base, but it was almost over run by the jihadists.Some of those involved in the assault were also foreign fighters.“We captured a Saudi and Afghani…and my [female] comrade shot a blonde European man in the head,” she states pointing near to the ISIS vehicle, where it happened.“He was about to enter our base and explode his suicide vest.”The SDF have recently redeployed some of their elite ‘counter terrorism units to Hajin to bolster their troops in the area.“We will begin the offensive against Hajin soon...but I don’t think this battle will be done quickly” the chief commander explains.“This is not a war that can be won quickly,” he added.Eventhe jihadists do lose Hajin this commander does not believe it will be the end of the terror group.“I am certain that they will be defeated here, but, that will not be the end of ISIS... and what may come after maybe worse, he adds.According to him this is a generational battle which cannot be defeated just by retaking territory.“At least now we and you know where ISIS is but after they are gone, they could attack from anywhere, even in Europe,” he says.In August Baghdadi urged his followers to unleash suicide bombs in the West, just days after he was reported to be brain dead.In the recorded message the worlds most wanted man urged fanatics to follow the striking lions behind recent lone wolf attacks in Europe and Canada.

title: you had one job images photos
story: Even something as simple as labelling a tin of butter correctly has been made a hash of and the people responsible for these hilarious snaps certainly wont be getting a promotion anytime soon.Sometimes the solutions to our everyday problems are so simple that we fail to see it when the answer is staring us right in the face.But even then, some problems can be too hard to deal with for some people.This hall of shame includes everything from grammar mistakes to other-worldly concepts.The outrageous gallery will have you chuckling at some of the funny ways people have mucked up a very simple job.

title: alana burns pregnant mum council flat bathgate west lothian
story: Alana Burns, , is due to give birth to twins in March and lives with children Alisha, two, Steven, four, Cayden, seven, Leigh, , and Caitlin, .Her older children Stewart, , and Bryan, , also live in the flat, which is above a pub in West Lothian.The home has four bedrooms but due to a leak in one room, the family are all crammed into just three bedrooms.They were living in a private let until the landlord decided to sell the property so they spent time in hotels before West Lothian Council found them the flat in September.Single mum Alana said: My relationship with some of my children is at breaking point. We cant keep living like this.The council has been out to the leak and said theyd get in touch with me, I have heard nothing.This has been going on for weeks and it needs sorting out.It is not safe for anyone to be sleeping in that room so were now down to eight people sharing three bedrooms which is ridiculous.I just want to get out of this hell. Id rather live anywhere , as long as it is not in here. It has been really tough.Im feeling down every night and sometimes you just feel like giving up. But I just have to keep going for the sake of the kids.The mum-to-be claims the run-down flat has a string of issues - including no TV, uneven flooring, damaged ceilings and noisy neighbours.She is having to pay out £ a day on electricity because she believes a third party is using her supply and says cant let her children out to play.Alana said: I need a proper house where I can bring up my children. The whole situation is unbelievable.My kids cant go out to play here.The road in front is busy and there is a car park at the back of the property so it isnt safe.All the kids are stuck inside all night crammed in without any TV.West Lothian Council confirmed previous repairs have already been carried out by the landlord and said they were only notied of the leak two days ago.A spokesman added: It can be challenging to find suitable accommodation for large families who present themselves as homeless, given the limited stock of larger homes available.In this case, the council arranged for temporary accommodation from a private landlord to try and meet their housing needs until a permanent home could be found.We would encourage Ms Burns to engage with the offers of support already made, to allow us to help find a solution for her familys housing needs.This includes widening her choice of areas to maximise her opportunities for permanent housing.

title: brexit deal theresa may leadership vote
story: The partys backbench chief Graham Brady will have to call a vote of confidence backbenchers request one.Senior Brexiteers from the European Research Group warned tonight that the threshold could be passed as soon as tomorrow.They insisted there is no co-ordinated plot to unseat the PM - but claimed MPs are so angry that  letters could end up going in anyway.Jacob Rees-Mogg said: The ERG is not trying to force the pace on this but there is the risk of an accident, a lot of people feel very let down and without any organisation might be writing letters.Conor Burns, a close ally of Boris Johnson, told LBC: There’s a lot of febrile talk. What I can tell you is there’s no orchestrated attempt to put letters in.But sensing the levels of frustration and annoyance colleagues are feeling it would not surprise meorganically letters are going in.The ERG has responded with fury to early reports of Mrs Mays Brexit deal.They claim it will leave the UK tied to the EU permanently thanks to the controversial Irish backstop meant to keep the border open.If Sir Graham, chair of the  Committee, receives  letters asking for a confidence vote, he must hold one within days.Mrs May will be kicked out of powershe fails to win the backing of  of the Tories  MPs.Butshe survives, the party cant hold another vote of confidence for at least a year.Some Brexiteers admit that the PM would probably win a vote - but forecast she would be so badly damaged she would have to ditch her current Brexit plans.

title: what is the draft brexit agreement theresa may
story: Heres what we know about the deal and what it could mean for the country.The full details have not yet been made public but Theresa May promised to present the deal to Parliament tomorrow morning in a formal Commons statement.The prime minister insisted that blocking her deal would mean going back to square one, with more ision and more uncertainty.May told the House of Commons earlier today: I am confident that this takes us signicantly closer to delivering what the British people voted for in the referendum.We will take back control of our borders, our laws and our money, leave the Common Fisheries Policy and the Common Agricultural Policy while protecting jobs, security and the integrity of our United Kingdom.She insisted the controversial Irish backstop will not keep Britain tied to the customs union for ever, saying: We dont want to be in a position where the European Union would find it comfortable to keep the UK in the backstop permanently.It also guarantees there will be no hard border between the UK and the Republic of Ireland.The PM faces a mighty showdown with her own backbenchers and the DUP - starting with a crunch meeting with chief unionist Arlene Foster due to take place tonight.Tory Brexiteers have even threatened to bring Mrs May down for good by forcing a vote of confidence in her leadership.Even half of the Cabinet spoke out against the deal before reluctantly agreeing to sign off on it in a bid to avoid the Government collapsing altogether.In a letter to Conservative MPs, European Research Group chairman Jacob Rees-Mogg said they should not support the deal.The proposals released today do not match the expectations set out in Theresa Mays Lancaster House speech, he said.The proposed agreement will see the UK hand over £ billion to the EU for little or nothing in , Mr Rees-Mogg said.The deal is unacceptable to unionists, will lock us into an EU customs union and EU laws and is profoundly undemocratic.For these reasons I can not support the proposed agreement in Parliament and would hope that Conservative MPs would do likewise, he said.The PM warned in her statement tonight that Britain faces a choice between her deal, a No Deal outcome or no Brexit at all, saying: I firmly believe that the draft withdrawal agreement was the best that could be negotiated, and it was for the Cabinet to decide whether to move on in the talks.The choices before us were dficult, particularly in relation to the Northern Ireland backstop.But the collective decision of Cabinet was that the Government should agree the draft withdrawal agreement and the outline political declaration.This is a decisive step which enables us to move on and finalise the deal in the days ahead.These decisions were not taken lightly but I believe it is a decision that is firmly in the national interest.Hinting at the trouble shes likely to face from rebellious MPs, Mrs May added: I know there will be dficult days ahead. This is a decision that will come under intense scrutiny and that is entirely as it should be and entirely understandable.She concluded: I believe that what I owe to this country is to take decisions in the national interest.I firmly believe with my head and my heart this is a decision which is in the best interests of our entire United Kingdom.

title: border shortage 620 staff shortage
story: Home Office civil servants yesterday revealed they were still  posts below the required level to be ‘Brexit ready’. Home Office mandarin Sir Philip Rutnam admitted the  wouldn’t be brought in until next summer.The startling admission stunned MPs on the Home Affairs Select Committee. And it came as Sir Philip admitted a No Deal would restrict the “leblood” of vital intelligence generated for police chiefs in the UK.He said that a decision would have to be made in the coming days on training up staff who currently work on IT systems and HR to prepare them to work across Britain’s borders.And – appearing before the Home Affairs Select Committee – he admitted Border Force would have to soon begin setting up a   ‘nerve centre’ similar to those in operation after terror attacks.He told MPs: “We are already signicantly increasing the level of activity around No Deal.“I would be expecting to make more redeployment decisions in December.”He added: “We are not at that point but we will be soon.”“We would have to be switching off other projects and capabilities to move into the execution of a No Deal plan.”The revelations come a day after a scathing report revealed overstretched Border Force staff cannot stop illegal migrants sneaking into Britain.An independent inspector said employees were being run ragged at ports across the south-coast by migrants armed with “better intel” than those out to stop them.Overall, Home Office officials claimed they were , short of its target staffing level for Brexit preparations - including the shortfall at the Border Office.Labour’s Yvette Cooper, HASC chair, said it was a “pretty stonking great gap”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
